Line 35: Line 35:
Canonical endorses and provides support for four additional Ubuntu-like operating systems: [[Kubuntu]], [[Xubuntu]], [[Edubuntu]] (a subproject and add-on for Ubuntu, designed for school environments and home users),<ref>{{cite web |title=Edubuntu - Frequently asked questions |url=http://www.edubuntu.org/faq |accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref> and [[Ubuntu JeOS]] (pronounced "Juice", a stripped-down version of Ubuntu optimized for [[virtual appliance]]s).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.vmware.com/console/2007/07/get-juiced.html|title=Get Juiced!<!-- Bot generated title --> |accessdate=2008-06-02|first=Srinivas|last=Krishnamurti }}</ref>
Canonical endorses and provides support for four additional Ubuntu-like operating systems: [[Kubuntu]], [[Xubuntu]], [[Edubuntu]] (a subproject and add-on for Ubuntu, designed for school environments and home users),<ref>{{cite web |title=Edubuntu - Frequently asked questions |url=http://www.edubuntu.org/faq |accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref> and [[Ubuntu JeOS]] (pronounced "Juice", a stripped-down version of Ubuntu optimized for [[virtual appliance]]s).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.vmware.com/console/2007/07/get-juiced.html|title=Get Juiced!<!-- Bot generated title --> |accessdate=2008-06-02|first=Srinivas|last=Krishnamurti }}</ref>
â
Canonical releases new versions of Ubuntu every six months and supports Ubuntu for eighteen months by providing security fixes, patches to critical bugs and minor updates to programs. LTS (Long Term Support) versions, which are released every two years,<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://www.markshuttleworth.com/archives/146 | authorlink = Mark Shuttleworth | title= Â» Blog Archive Â» The Art of Release | accessdate = 2008-05-13 | last = Shuttleworth | first = Mark }}</ref> are supported for three years on the desktop and five years for servers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ubuntu.com/news/ubuntu-8.04-lts-desktop|title=Ubuntu 8.04 LTS Desktop Edition Released|publisher=www.ubuntu.com|accessdate=2008-05-13}}</ref> The current version of Ubuntu, ''Jaunty [[Jackalope]]'', was released on April 23, 2009, and the upcoming version, ''Karmic [[Koala]]'', is expected to be released on 29 October 2009.
+
Canonical releases new versions of Ubuntu every six months and supports Ubuntu for eighteen months by providing security fixes, patches to critical bugs and minor updates to programs. LTS (Long Term Support) versions, which are released every two years,<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://www.markshuttleworth.com/archives/146 | authorlink = Mark Shuttleworth | title= Â» Blog Archive Â» The Art of Release | accessdate = 2008-05-13 | last = Shuttleworth | first = Mark }}</ref> are supported for three years on the desktop and five years for servers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ubuntu.com/news/ubuntu-8.04-lts-desktop|title=Ubuntu 8.04 LTS Desktop Edition Released|publisher=www.ubuntu.com|accessdate=2008-05-13}}</ref> The current version of Ubuntu, ''9.04'', was released on April 23, 2009, and the upcoming version, ''Karmic [[Koala]]'', is expected to be released on 29 October 2009.
